title: 114_s2327
content: The "Foster EITC Act of 2015" is the short title of the Act. It includes a permanent extension of modifications to the Earned Income Tax Credit. The "Foster EITC Act of 2015" includes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, such as increasing the credit percentage for families with 3 or more children and raising the limit for joint returns from $3,000 to $5,000. The "Foster EITC Act of 2015" raises the limit for joint returns from $3,000 to $5,000, with inflation adjustments and conforming amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The effective date for these changes is taxable years beginning after December 31, 2014. The "Foster EITC Act of 2015" increases the limit for joint returns to $5,000 with inflation adjustments, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2014. The "Foster EITC Act of 2015" raises the credit for individuals with no qualifying children in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, increasing the amounts to $8,820 and $10,425. The table in section 32(b)(1)(A) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the credit for individuals with no children to $8,820 and $10,425. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to change the age requirement for tax credits from "age 25" to "age 21 (or age 18 for youth formerly in foster care)." Additionally, a new definition is provided for "youth formerly in foster care" as individuals who were in foster care at or after the age of 16. A new section is added for tax returns related to youth in foster care. "SEC. 6050X. RETURNS RELATING TO YOUTH IN FOSTER CARE." Any State, local, or tribal agency responsible for reporting data to the Adoption and Foster Care Analysis and Reporting System must submit a return for individuals in foster care over the age of 16. Once a return is made for an individual, subsequent returns for that individual in future years are not required unless specified by the Secretary. The return must be in the form and manner prescribed by the Secretary. The return for individuals in foster care over 16 must be in the form prescribed by the Secretary and include specific information for each individual. Furnishing a written statement to individuals is required for those whose information is included in the return. The return for individuals in foster care over 16 must include a written statement with the person's name, address, phone number, and required information by January 31 of the following year. Penalties for non-compliance are outlined in the Code. The Code requires returns relating to youth in foster care to be submitted by January 31 of the following year, with penalties for non-compliance outlined. Sec. 6050X requires returns for youth in foster care to be filed by January 31 of the following year, with penalties for non-compliance. Effective after December 31, 2014. Also, simplifying the Earned Income Tax Credit. Modification of Abandoned Spouse Rule: Section 32(c)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include provisions for married individuals living apart with a qualifying child for more than half of the year. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include provisions for married individuals living apart with a qualifying child for more than half of the year, and specifies that individuals with a legally binding separation agreement and not living in the same household as their spouse by the end of the taxable year shall not be considered married. Amendments are made to sections 32(c)(1)(A) and 32(d) of the Code. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to simplify rules for married individuals with a qualifying child and those not described in subsection (c)(1)(H). Taxpayers may be eligible for the worker tax credit without a qualifying child if the child is claimed by another family member. Individuals who may claim as a qualifying child for a taxable year, if claimed by an eligible individual, can be considered eligible without a qualifying child for the tax credit. An exception applies if the qualifying child is claimed by a parent. An eligible individual with a qualifying child can claim the tax credit. If a parent claims the child, no other custodial parent without a claim can be considered eligible for the credit. Individuals without a valid social security number for their qualifying children can still be eligible for the credit. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2014.
